TEXT.citation: Early, R. J., & Whitehorn, J. (2003). One hundred Paiwan texts. Pacific Linguistics, Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies, The Australian National University.
TEXT.BibTeX_citation: @book{100paiwantexts, author = {Robert Early and John Whitehorn}, title = {One Hundred Paiwan Texts}, year = {2003}, publisher = {Pacific Linguistics, Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies, The Australian National University}}

S.FORM: izua azazua qinałan i Kałuyung, matjaeneenem a umaq, aya a tjautsikel.
izoa azazoa qinaljan i Kaljoyong, matjaeneenem a omaq, aya a tjaocikel.
S.TRANSL: There was a village at Kałuyung with six households, according to the story.

S.FORM: sa manu a qemałup a sema zua i Łaitaw.
sa mano a qemaljop a sema zoa i Ljaitaw.
S.TRANSL: They went hunting to Łaitaw.

S.FORM: ka tsemikel anga maqepu azua izua i Putjazaran i pasalaulauz i Kałuyung a namaqepu.
ka cemikel anga maqepo azoa izoa i Potjazaran i pasalaolaoz i Kaljoyong a namaqepo.
S.TRANSL: When they got back, they gathered at Putjazaran in the lower part of Kałuyung.

S.FORM: manu "patsuni aken," aya zua ti sa Tsudjuy, nu vetseluqen a kasiw a papetsevutsevungen.
mano "paconi aken," aya zoa ti sa Codjoy, no veceloqen a kasiw a papecevocevongen.
S.TRANSL: “Look at me!” said Tsudjuy, while he broke trees which had been put together.

S.FORM: "aku maya?" aya a salasaladj.
"ako maya?" aya a salasaladj.
S.TRANSL: “Why can he do that?” said his companions,

S.FORM: mavilad a sema umaq.
mavilad a sema omaq.
S.TRANSL: and ran away to their homes.

S.FORM: ka tjaivilił anga azua ti sa Tsudjuy tjelu anga a qadaw tu qinałupan.
ka tjaivililj anga azoa ti sa Codjoy tjelo anga a qadaw to qinaljopan.
S.TRANSL: Afterwards Tsudjuy went hunting for three days.

S.FORM: "aku maya sun?" ayain nua mamazangiłan.
"ako maya son?" ayain noa mamazangiljan.
S.TRANSL: “Why are you like that?” asked the chief.

S.FORM: manu "aki ken a makuda aya a ventseluq tua kasiw?" aya zazua.
mano "aki ken a makoda aya a venceloq toa kasiw?" aya zazoa.
S.TRANSL: “Why am I able to break trees like that?”(?) he said.

S.FORM: łakua "uri kitjutapaw aken.
ljakoa "ori kitjotapaw aken.
S.TRANSL: But “I’ll live in a house apart.

S.FORM: saka nu masan palak aken, maya kidut; matsay mun," ayain azua salasaladj.
saka no masan palak aken, maya kidot; macay mon," ayain azoa salasaladj.
S.TRANSL: When I am possessed, don’t come near; you’ll die,” he said to his companions.

S.FORM: sa vaik azua a seman djalan tu sisa tjatjan.
sa vaik azoa a seman djalan to sisa tjatjan.
S.TRANSL: He went to make a path leading to a spring.

S.FORM: ka maqatsuvung a seman djalan, seman djalungan pizua i vetsekadan tua djełeqi; saka maqatsuvung anga azua sinan tjatjan.
ka maqacovong a seman djalan, seman djalongan pizoa i vecekadan toa djeljeqi; saka maqacovong anga azoa sinan tjatjan.
S.TRANSL: When he had finished making the path, he made a well in the middle of a rock-face; and so the spring was finished.

S.FORM: saka vaik a kikasiw tu sisan tapaw.
saka vaik a kikasiw to sisan tapaw.
S.TRANSL: Then he went to get wood to make a house.

S.FORM: łakua inika masi tjakit, inika masi putjaw; vetseluqen tua lima.
ljakoa inika masi tjakit, inika masi potjaw; veceloqen toa lima.
S.TRANSL: But he didn’t use a knife or axe; he broke trees with his hands.

S.FORM: saka nu masi kasiw, makatał tua sialangan.
saka no masi kasiw, makatalj toa sialangan.
S.TRANSL: When he carried the wood, he carried all the rafters in one journey.

S.FORM: sa kiqatsiłay tu siupu makapusał, vinatsaq tua sialangan.
sa kiqaciljay to siopo makaposalj, vinacaq toa sialangan.
S.TRANSL: He collected stones for the walls in two journeys, carrying them with a rafter for a pole.

S.FORM: sa vaik anga a kitsukes; kimaya ḍusa tjatał a pasa melava, saka pasa laḍuq kimaya tjelu a tjatał.
sa vaik anga a kicokes; kimaya drosa tjatalj a pasa melava, saka pasa ladroq kimaya tjelo a tjatalj.
S.TRANSL: He went to get pillars; they were about two arm spans wide and three arm spans long.

S.FORM: saka maqatsuvung anga kiniqepu, sa san tapaw anga zazua, aya.
saka maqacovong anga kiniqepo, sa san tapaw anga zazoa, aya.
S.TRANSL: He finished collecting the materials, and made a house, they say.

S.FORM: saka "aku izua zazua a pupitsul a mamaw tu tsemas?" aya.
saka "ako izoa zazoa a popicol a mamaw to cemas?" aya.
S.TRANSL: “Why is he as strong as a god?” said his former companions,

S.FORM: saka samałi aravats azua salasaladj, aya a tjautsikel.
saka samalji aravac azoa salasaladj, aya a tjaocikel.
S.TRANSL: very surprised, according to the story.
